The downside allows any outsider to deliver a booby-trapped message that may erase a personal computer's hard drive or even take information. Most e-mail attacks involve devices that are harmless unless the user runs the actual attached program. The brand new flaw, however, is not so easily prevented. In some test circumstances, simply trying to remove email activated the attack. The assaults cannot be guarded towards with "firewalls" or anti-viral software, two widely used safety methods. Finnish researchers discovered the problem last month. To date, tests have shown it is presence in about three programs widely used to learn electronic mail: Microsoft Corp.'s Outlook Express and Outlook 98 along with Netscape Communications Corp.'s latest Web browser, Communicator. Netscape and Microsoft have been informed of the problem. Microsof company has devised an application patch that is now available at its Web site. Netscape's patch is expected quickly at its Web page. "We're definitely not taking this casually," Microsoft class product manager George Meng told the San Jose Mercury Media. "There definitely is a scenario through which someone could accomplish damage to people's methods." Microsoft, in its Web site, said the flaw affects versions of Outlook Express shipped along with Microsoft Internet Explorer 4.0 or Some.01 on Windows 98, Windows 89, Windows NT 4.0 and Windows NT with regard to DEC Alpha, along with Windows versions for Macintosh or UNIX models. The company said people that use Windows 3.1 and Windows NT Three.51 operating systems are not affected.
